name: Blog Layout (List and Post)
description: A comprehensive blog layout covering the list frontpage (post cards, grid, pagination) and single post layout (article, sidebar, comments, related posts). Includes all UI sections typically needed in blogs: navbar, hero, post list, post card, post header, article content, sidebar, newsletter, footer, pagination, comments, share buttons.

default.name: Editorial
default.postListColumnsNote: 2 columns when sidebar is visible for better card sizing; 3 columns only when sidebar is hidden

invariants: Sections stack vertically in source order
Entire page scrolls (no nested scroll containers)
Navbar remains fixed or sticky during scroll
No horizontal page scroll is introduced
Blog list and post layouts share navbar and footer
Optional sidebar sits beside main content on desktop

aiAgentInstructions.summary: Implement a complete, production-grade blog layout covering both the list frontpage and single post page. Prioritize visual polish, scannability, and readability: clear hierarchy, refined spacing rhythm, strong typography, and cohesive card system. The layout is framework-agnostic and adapts to the user's stack and styling approach.
keyFeatures: Blog list page: hero (optional), post grid/cards (2 columns on desktop with sidebar, 3 without), pagination, optional sidebar (categories, tags, search, newsletter)

Post page: article header (full-width hero with title, meta, author, reading time), content area (constrained width for readability), optional sidebar (TOC, author bio, related posts), comments, share buttons, related posts
Post card component: featured image, title, excerpt, date, author, category/tags with consistent card styling and hover feedback
Shared navbar and footer across list and post pages
Optional sidebar collapses or moves below content on mobile
Pagination with prev/next and page numbers
Strong visual hierarchy with an editorial feel (hero emphasis, section rhythm, typographic contrast)
Reading-first article typography (16-18px body, optimized measure, generous line-height, clear heading cadence)
Consistent visual system for surfaces: cards, side panels, forms, and footer blocks
Modern 2026 blog styling patterns: clean whitespace, bold heading hierarchy, subtle motion, meaningful imagery
Quality contract: outputs must show intentional hierarchy, depth layering, and consistent interaction states, not plain starter defaults
CRITICAL: Styling MUST match the project's existing conventions. Detect framework and styling system first.
CRITICAL: Avoid generic starter UI look. Apply explicit designSystem values for spacing, typography, color, border radius, and shadows.
CRITICAL: When vanilla CSS is detected, ALWAYS create CSS classes in a stylesheet. NEVER use inline style attributes.
CRITICAL: When React is detected, extract logic into separate custom hooks that do ONE thing each.
implementationSteps: 0. CRITICAL: Detect the project's framework and styling system BEFORE writing any code. Examine package.json, existing components, config files, and style structure. Use ONLY the detected system.
0a. Detect framework patterns: component structure, routing, state management.
0b. Detect styling conventions: class naming, design tokens, imports.
0c. If detection is uncertain, ask the user about framework and styling.
1. Create shared layout shell: Navbar, Footer, main content wrapper
2. Implement blog list page: hero (optional), post grid with PostCard components (2 columns on desktop if sidebar present, 3 if no sidebar), pagination
3. Build PostCard component: image, title, excerpt, date, author, category/tags
4. Implement post page: article header (full-width hero with title, meta, author, reading time, featured image), article content (constrained width ~720px for readability), optional sidebar
5. Add sidebar component: categories, tags, search, newsletter signup (list page); TOC, author bio, related posts (post page)
6. Implement pagination component: prev/next links, page numbers
7. Add newsletter signup section (form or link)
8. Add comments section placeholder structure
9. Add share buttons component
10. Add related posts section on post page
11. Apply visual hierarchy pass: hero prominence, section spacing rhythm, consistent component density, card/media treatment
11a. Run Modern UI quality gate before finalizing: check visual hierarchy, spacing rhythm, surface consistency, and interaction polish.
12. Implement responsive breakpoints (mobile: 1 col, tablet: 2 cols, desktop: 2 cols with sidebar or 3 without) and preserve visual quality at each size
13. Ensure all interactive elements are keyboard accessible
14. Add semantic HTML5 and ARIA attributes
15. Add subtle motion (card hover, reveal, sticky navbar transitions) with reduced-motion fallback
16. Use ONLY the detected styling system.

modernUiQualityContract.intent: Keep the output visually current without prescribing exact fonts, libraries, or brand styles.
principles: Use one coherent surface system across cards, panels, forms, and navigation (matching radius, border, depth, and hover logic).
Create strong first-screen hierarchy: clear dominant headline, clear secondary metadata, and obvious primary actions.
Use layered depth intentionally (background layers, section separation, or subtle elevation), but keep content readability first.
Maintain spacing rhythm across sections so vertical flow feels designed, not accidental.
Treat interactive states as part of design quality: hover, focus-visible, active, and disabled must be deliberate and consistent.
compositionRules: At least one high-emphasis section (hero or article header) should establish visual identity immediately.
Utility/sidebar blocks should look related but less dominant than primary reading content.
Card grids should prioritize readability and scan speed before density.
Visual accents should be reused intentionally (not random per component).
antiPatterns: Unstyled framework starter aesthetics (plain centered demo layout, default button/input look).
Mixing multiple unrelated visual systems on one page.
Overloaded decoration that reduces contrast or reading comfort.

minimumCriteria: Above-the-fold area has a clear visual focal point and readable supporting content.
Cards, side panels, and forms share a unified surface language.
Interactive elements have visible default, hover, and focus-visible states.
Section spacing follows a repeatable rhythm across the whole page.
Final UI does not look like a scaffold/template starter.
selfReviewQuestions: Can a user identify primary content and secondary utilities in under 3 seconds?
Does the page still feel cohesive when viewed at mobile, tablet, and desktop breakpoints?
If component labels were removed, would the visual hierarchy still be obvious?

framework.description: Detect the project's framework by examining package.json, existing component files, and project structure.
detectionSteps: Check package.json for framework dependencies (react, vue, @angular/core, svelte)
Examine existing component files for framework-specific patterns

stylingSystem.description: Detect the project's styling approach. Use the detected system exclusively.
detectionSteps: Check package.json for styling dependencies: tailwindcss, styled-components, emotion, sass, etc.
Look for config files: tailwind.config.js, postcss.config.js, etc.
Examine existing component files to see how styles are imported and used
Check for style files and their extensions
Identify class naming conventions and utility functions
adaptationRules: If Tailwind is detected: Use Tailwind utility classes exclusively
If SCSS/CSS is detected: Create SCSS/CSS files matching project structure
If styled-components is detected: Use styled-components syntax
If CSS Modules is detected: Use .module.css files
If no styling system: Use vanilla CSS with semantic class names

designTokens.description: Identify existing design tokens from the project. Use these instead of hardcoding values.
detectionSteps: Check for design token files (tokens.json, theme.js, etc.)
Examine Tailwind config for theme values if using Tailwind
Look at existing components for color, spacing, and typography patterns
Check CSS variables (--color-*, --spacing-*, etc.) in global styles

must: Use ONLY project's framework and styling system
Semantic HTML5 (header, main, article, nav, footer)
Use designSystem visual values (color, typography, spacing, radius, shadow) as explicit implementation contract
Create a cohesive editorial visual hierarchy (hero prominence, readable cards, calm article typography)
Keep article measure in readable range and preserve spacing rhythm across sections
Apply Modern UI quality gate from implementationDetails.modernUiQualityContract before final output
mustNot: Use inline styles when vanilla CSS detected
Put multiple concerns in single React useEffect
Ship generic starter-style blog UI with unstyled/plain sections
Mix inconsistent card styles in the same page (different radius, borders, and shadow logic)
Rely on default component styling without intentional hierarchy and interaction polish
